License Chooser Tool Redesign

Four week collaboration with the Creative Commons to redesign the License Chooser Tool on desktop, mobile, and third party platforms.

Client

Creative Commons

Duration

4 weeks

Team

Conner Hunihan

My Role

UX Designer
Visual Designer
Project Manager

Skills

User Testing
Prototyping
Design System
Multi-device Design

Project Background

The Creative COmmons

The Creative Commons (CC) is a non-profit dedicated to expanding the range of creative works available for others to build upon levally and to share. The organization has developed several copyright-licenses known as Creative Commons licenses that help content creators protect their work by licensing it free of charge to the public.

The CC USability Initiative

In January 2018, CC kicked off the CC Usability Initiative to update the experience of CC licensing and discovery to reflect the realities of digital sharing in 2018, and to antiripate and design for the future of digital content sharing. After six months of user research, CC revealed nine core insights and green lit six project concepts for prototyping. The Creative Commons partnered with individual students from INFO290: Product Studio Design to realize three of those concepts, collaborating directly with the Director of Product & Research, Jane Park.

Key Insights

Licenses are not understood

The research phase of CC Usability yielded two significant challenges in the process of finding and applying a license. The first was the realization that while people understand that CC stands for free content sharing, the specifics of licensing were not clearly understood.

"I've been using CC for years and I couldn't explain the differences between the license options to you."

— Multimedia Artist, CC Usability Update for Public

The Licensing Process is not understood

A second insight that came out of the CC Usability findings was that while people are motivated to license their work under CC, they have a hard time figuring out how to do so. While some of this uncertainty could be addressed through a redesign of the License Chooser Tool on the CC website, the issue of figuring out how to apply a license most frequently presents itself on third-party platforms at the moment when users first upload content.

"An event producer and artist says he's always meant to CC license some of his work, but has never gotten around to it. "Maybe if it was more easier, like swipe up to license...""

Excerpt from the CC Usability Update for Public

Further, licenses need to be attached to the work they are being applied to, and since digital work is hosted on third-party platforms (YouTube, Flikr, Medium), the introduction of users to CC licensing is often left to those third-party platforms to design.

This has lead to a lack of standardization across platforms, as well as feeling of loss of control by users.

Final Project Scope

Constraints

Working directly with CC staff, the constraints for the project were finalized. CC users needed a way to not only find the license they needed, but to learn about the selection process along the way. The design of such a selector tool also needed to be portable across platforms, in order to offer third-party content hosting platforms a standardized template.

How might the design of the license chooser tool empower users to better understand the process and intricacies of the license they are selecting?

Target User

A single user persona – Paulo – was developed to ground design critique. Paulo is a typical user; he is a University professor who wrote a paper that was recently cited by a publishing group, The Converation. As part of his research, Paulo produces many types of content, uses many tools, and stores his content on multiple platforms. For Paulo, his content is his life’s work, and so it is important not only to be able to share it, but to protect it.
For Paulo, act of sharing is a statement.

Deliverables

The final deliverable for the project would be a high-fidelity prototype of a License Selector feature to replace the existing selector tool on the CC website. The design was to address selection on both mobile and desktop devices, and also needed to integrate with a third-party platform.

Existing License Chooser Tool

Explorations

Foundations of the Design

Testing existing tools with users and exploring not only the CC website, but the broader content licensing landscape revealed three bright spots that would become the foundation for the design:

Provide Context

Users responded strongly to this graphic on the CC website, which orders CC licenses along a dimension of restriction.

Explain Components

The CC website has a page that outlines the fundamental building blocks of every license.

Modularize Selection Process

Third-party platforms like Medium have already integrated CC license selection into the uploading process.

A New Metaphor

These foundations were used to develop a new metaphor for the design – making a recipe.

Shopping List
Create a list of the "ingredients" to be used. This is provided by titrating the explanation of the license components into increasingly detailed levels of exploration.

Shopping Cart
Explore the store, pick items up, put items down. We encourage such exploration through an interactive matrix that allows for attribute-based comparison.

Recipe
Follow the recipe to turn those ingredients into a meal. In licensing terminology, this means instructing people on the process of how to actually apply the license they have just selected.

Shopping List

Before users can choose a license, they need to understand the licenses. An interactive graphic facilitates exploration of the "ingredients" users will need.

Shopping Cart

Once users understand what it is they are looking for, it is time to make a choise. Offering this selection via a matrix allows for comparison across licenses.

Recipe

Once theie license has been generated, users need to be instructed on how to actually apply the license, as the process is different, depending on whether the content is self-hosted, on a third-party platform, or needs plaintext application.

Left on the cutting room floor

While a matrix mechanism allowed for the greatest degree of exploration and context-setting, two other selection mechanisms were considered:

Best-of-Three

Minimize choice aversion by offering a recommended option, as well as two attribute-based alternatives. While this streamlined the selection process, users found it too simplistic, “my work is too important…I need to know more about the details of this license before I can trust it.""

Wizard

The existing mechanic and, from a decisional perspective, the most usable. However, a wizard does not facilitate exploration outside of the confines of the component, resulting in long-time users who, while they have the correct license, do not undertsand it.

Multi-device Prototype

Mobile Design

The final design holds selection as the primary focus, but around that skeleton, introduces opportunities to explore the licensing process. Users can dive deeper into the technical language, see how attribution will look, and explore real-world examples that have used this license.

Desktop Design

Desktop allows for more detail upfront, essentially bringing the component summaries to the main hero section of the page. Nonetheless, selection is still the primary function of the feature.

Third-Party Integration

While a Creative Commons License Chooser add on already exists for Google Documents, conference presentations are high on the list of content Paulo wants to license. A Google Slides add on was therefore designed to demonstrate the integration of the revised Lisence Chooser Tool on a third-party platform.

Handover

Style Guide + Design System

The design necessitated extending the existing Creative Common's style guide. As such, a light design system was developed to document the typography, colors, and component details.

Next steps

The desktop and mobile prototypes have been staged for development, and can be viewed along with other prototypes developed as part of the CC Usability Initiative at this GitHub repository.

The Google Slides add on has also been staged for production. If you would like to learn more or get involved, visit the GitHub repo, here.
